Las cláusulas de complemento Esta sección considera varios tipos de cláusulas subordinadas que son complementos de verbos principales o de adjetivos que funcionan igual que el predicado de la oración, como los siguientes ejemplos del inglés.
I believe that Jill is my friend. ‘Creo que Juliana es mi amiga.' Jill insists that she is my friend. ‘Juliana insiste que ella sea mi amiga.' I expect that Joe will come to the party. ‘Cuento con que José venga a la fiesta.' I expect Joe to come to the party. ‘Espero que José venga a la fiesta.' I will persuade Joe that he should come to the party. ‘Persuadiré a José que él debe venir a la fiesta.' I will persuade Joe to come to the party. ‘Persuadiré a José de venir a la fiesta.' Joe would hate for Sue to be at the party. ‘José odiaría que Susana esté en la fiesta.' Joe tried to come to the party. ‘José intentó venir a la fiesta.' John seemed to like the tortillas. ‘Juan parecía tener gusto de las tortillas.' It seems likely that Joe will come. ‘Parece probable que vendrá José.'
Los causativos sintácticos que consisten en dos cláusulas, como en ejemplos 11-12, se cubren aquí también. (Los causativos morfológicos que consisten en una sola cláusula se tratan en
Las oraciones básicas - Causativas y antipasivas.)
My mother made me clean my room. ‘Mi madre me hizo limpiar mi dormitorio.' The other girl caused us to break up. ‘La otra muchacha hizo que nos separáramos.'
Discurso directo e indirecto, como se muestran en ejemplos 13-14, pueden ser cláusulas de complemento como se presentan en esta sección. Sin embargo, las preguntas subordinadas se analizan en
Las preguntas.
Sue said, “I will come to your house tomorrow.” ‘Susana dijo, “Vendré a su casa mañana”.' Sue said (to me) that she would come here tomorrow. ‘Susana me dijo (a mí) que ella vendría aquí mañana.'
The examples illustrate that the main verb selects one or more particular types of complement clauses which can occur gramatically. For example, try cannot have a complement clause beginning with that and the subject of the embedded clause must be coreferent to the main clause subject and pro-dropped. Further, believe, insist and persuade cannot have a complement clause beginning with for and none of the verbs above can have an embedded question complement.
A second point the examples illustrate is that the presence of a particular complementizer determines the finiteness of the embedded verb which follows it. This evidence of subcategorization by the main verb for the complementizer and by the complementizer for the embedded verb form leads to the conclusion that the complementizer is the head of the embedded clause. Therefore, within X-Bar Theory, embedded clauses which have complementizers are CPs, which sit on top of the IP.

Finally, verbs like seem ( including other perception verbs and copulas) are called ‘raising' verbs, since seem doesn't really have its own subject, and takes either a nonfinite sentence as a complement or an adjective which can have a finite sentence with a complementizer as its complement. In the nonfinite case (9), the subject of the complement appears in the subject postion of seem. In the finite complement case, there is no overt subject for seem, so a “dummy” word it fills that position in English. Some languages simply leave the main clause subject postion empty.
A tree for example 9 with a nonfinite IP complement and coreferent subjects due to raising will look just like the tree for example 8 with try, since we are not modelling the null elements. Similarly, a tree for example 10 would be vey similar to the tree above for example 1 with believe, except for the adjective complement and the dummy it in the main clause subject position.

Los ejemplos ilustran que el verbo principal selecciona uno o más tipos particulares de cláusulas de complemento que puedan presentarse gramaticalmente. Por ejemplo, try ‘intentar' no puede tener un a cláusula de complemento que empieza con that ‘que' y el sujeto de la cláusula subordinada debe ser coreferente al sujeto de la cláusula principal y sea faltado. Además, believe ‘creer', insist ‘insistir' y persuade ‘persuadir' no pueden tener un a cláusula de complemento que empieza con for ‘para' y ningún verbo antedicho puede tener un complemento interrogativo.
